skill.name: building-mcp-servers
skill.description:
Guides creation of high-quality MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers that enable LLMs
to interact with external services through well-designed tools. Use when building MCP
servers to integrate external APIs or services, whether in Python (FastMCP) or
Node/TypeScript (MCP SDK). Covers tool design, authentication, Docker deployment,
and evaluation creation. NOT when consuming existing MCP servers (use the server directly).

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation/guide skill containing markdown reference files and utility scripts for building MCP servers. All 575 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES - the analyzer misinterprets markdown code examples as executable security issues. The scripts (evaluation.py, connections.py) are legitimate MCP evaluation utilities using standard, documented patterns.

content.user_title: Build MCP Servers for Claude Integration
content.value_statement: Create MCP servers that enable Claude and other LLMs to interact with external APIs and services through well-designed tools. This guide covers Python FastMCP and TypeScript MCP SDK implementations with authentication, Docker deployment, and testing patterns.
actual_capabilities: Create MCP servers using Python FastMCP or TypeScript MCP SDK
Design effective tool schemas with Pydantic and Zod validation
Implement authentication patterns with environment variables
Deploy MCP servers with Docker and configure transport security
Create comprehensive evaluations for testing MCP server effectiveness
limitations: This is a guide skill - it provides documentation and patterns but does not execute code or connect to actual APIs
Does not provide pre-built MCP servers for specific services
Does not handle runtime authentication or credential management

use_cases.title: Integrate external services with Claude
use_cases.description: Build custom MCP servers to connect Claude with APIs like GitHub, Slack, or Jira for seamless service integration

use_cases.title: Deploy production MCP servers
use_cases.description: Containerize MCP servers with Docker, configure transport security, and set up health check endpoints

use_cases.title: Test MCP server effectiveness
use_cases.description: Create evaluation frameworks to measure how well LLMs can use your MCP server tools for complex tasks

prompt_templates.title: Create basic MCP server
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a basic MCP server structure in Python using FastMCP for a GitHub integration. Include tool naming conventions and authentication setup.

prompt_templates.title: Add pagination support
prompt_templates.prompt: Add pagination support to a list_repos tool in my MCP server. Show how to implement offset-based pagination with limit, offset, and has_more parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Configure Docker deployment
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure my Python MCP server for Docker deployment with Streamable HTTP transport. Include allowed_hosts configuration for container-to-container communication.

prompt_templates.title: Create evaluation framework
prompt_templates.prompt: Create 10 evaluation questions for my MCP server that test whether LLMs can effectively use the tools to answer complex, realistic queries about historical data.

output_examples.input: Create a TypeScript MCP server tool that searches users with pagination support
output: Tool name: example_search_users (snake_case with service prefix)
Input schema with Zod validation: query string, limit 1-100, offset >= 0
Response includes: total count, users array with id, name, email, team, has_more flag
Annotations: readOnlyHint: true, destructiveHint: false, idempotentHint: true, openWorldHint: true

output_examples.input: How do I configure transport security for a FastMCP server in Docker?
output: Pass transport_security parameter to FastMCP constructor
This validates Host headers and prevents DNS rebinding attacks

output_examples.input: What makes a good MCP evaluation question?
output: Requires deep exploration with multiple tool calls
Has a single, verifiable answer that won't change over time
Reflects realistic human use cases LLMs would help with

best_practices: Use consistent tool naming with service prefixes (github_create_issue) to avoid conflicts when using multiple MCP servers
Implement pagination with limit, offset, and has_more to prevent overwhelming LLMs with large result sets
Design tools with clear input schemas using Pydantic or Zod for validation, and provide actionable error messages
anti_patterns: Avoid generic tool names like send_message or create that may conflict with other MCP servers
Do not return all data without pagination - this causes LLMs to run out of context
Avoid tools that modify state without clear readOnlyHint and destructiveHint annotations

faq.question: What transport should I use for my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use Streamable HTTP for remote servers with multiple clients. Use stdio for local integrations and CLI tools.

faq.question: How many tools should an MCP server have?
faq.answer: Focus on comprehensive API coverage with focused tools. Each tool should do one thing well with clear descriptions.

faq.question: How do I handle authentication in MCP servers?
faq.answer: Store API keys in environment variables. Validate credentials on server startup. Use OAuth 2.1 for services that support it.

faq.question: What are MCP tool annotations?
faq.answer: Annotations (readOnlyHint, destructiveHint, idempotentHint, openWorldHint) help LLMs understand tool behavior and make better choices.

faq.question: How do I test if my MCP server works well?
faq.answer: Create evaluation questions that require multiple tool calls. Test whether LLMs can discover and use tools effectively to answer complex questions.

faq.question: Can I use this skill to build MCP servers for any service?
faq.answer: Yes, the patterns apply to any REST API. Follow the research phase to study API documentation, then implement tools for common operations.
